Okay, as others have said, now for history of other regions.  Latin American, for example, or other areas - Asian is probably too broad, as there is a huge difference among Middle Eastern, Central Asian, South Asian, and East Asian (though there is some overlap, as the borders of the regions aren't defined - Middle Eastern, for example, today generally includes North Africa, though that's a fairly recent development; also, Afghanistan could be considered either Middle Eastern or Central Asian, depending on the drawn lines, though Central Asian usually means the former Soviet states of Asia).  Also, Africa is also such a huge continent with many many cultures that we in the West kinda just squeeze into two large areas - North Africa and Sub-Saharan Africa, even though life in Ghana is far different than life in Kenya, and both have different cultures than South Africa.  Yet we in the West just gloss over them.  So a series (or 2 or 3) on Sub-Saharan African histories and cultures would be extremely helpful.

I work as a translator of oral histories, focusing on Yiddish language testimonies of Holocaust survivors which were made in the 1970s, before Holocaust history focused heavily on survivor testimony. These testimonies are incredible and terrifying. The things and ways people remembered the worst things imaginable is fascinating. For example one man could recall hour by hour the day his town was occupied by the Nazis, and continued to remember the days of the week throughout his time surviving in hiding. When I cross referenced his memories with German war plans, I was able to determine that he remembered the battle accurately down to the time of day. Another man remembered very precisely the order in which things happened, and could remember how long he was kept in certain camps, but was unable to recall in which year something happened. These were not old men, they were in their 50s at the time of recording, but they remembered their Holocaust experiences very differently, likely due to trauma. The man who remembered time very well survived in hiding, while the man who remembered time in a much more disjointed way survived two death camps and several concentration camps. The history of the Holocaust is vast, and survivor testimonies show just how vast and diverse the history is.
